content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 3 column table with 3 rows of data. The heading for column 1 is “x,” the heading for column 2 is “f of x,” and the heading for column 3 is “f prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Row 1. x is 3. f of x is negative 1. f prime of x is 8. Row 2. x is 5. f of x is 4. f prime of x is 3. Row 3. x is 7. f of x is 6. f prime of x is negative 2."><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0em" columnwidth="3em 0.05em 3em 3em" equalrows="false" frame="solid" framespacing="0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05em" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> The table above gives values of the differentiable function <math alttext="f"><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></math> and its derivative <math alttext="f prime"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> at selected values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="h"><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x, equals, x squared, times e raised to the cosine of open parenthesis, 3 x, close parenthesis, power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Using values of <math alttext="f"><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></math> from the table, estimate <math alttext="f prime of 4"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 3 column table with 3 rows of data. The heading for column 1 is “x,” the heading for column 2 is “f of x,” and the heading for column 3 is “f prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Row 1. x is 3. f of x is negative 1. f prime of x is 8. Row 2. x is 5. f of x is 4. f prime of x is 3. Row 3. x is 7. f of x is 6. f prime of x is negative 2."><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0em" columnwidth="3em 0.05em 3em 3em" equalrows="false" frame="solid" framespacing="0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05em" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> The table above gives values of the differentiable function <math alttext="f"><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></math> and its derivative <math alttext="f prime"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> at selected values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="h"><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x, equals, x squared, times e raised to the cosine of open parenthesis, 3 x, close parenthesis, power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Using values of <math alttext="f"><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></math> from the table, estimate <math alttext="f prime of 4"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(b) Let <math alttext="M"><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="M of x, equals, f of x, plus h of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="M prime of 3"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Let <math alttext="N"><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="N of x, equals, f of x, times, h of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="N prime of 5"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Let <math alttext="P"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="P of x, equals, the fraction h of x, over, f of x, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="P prime of 7"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 2.3: Estimating Derivatives of a Function at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
